body.p:
I received your sundry favors 2nd
March & 2nd May, & 21st August, together with all the missing
occidents, and a letter from Mr. J. J. Seixas explaining the
detentions of those letters and books having been occasioned
by the negligence of our New York agents, which I regret
as it has been the cause of my loosing many subscribers, I was
reduced to 5, but since the books have arrived I have got 2 more
thus now I have 7 subscribers. In my last I informed you
of my having disposed of one Sett of Prayer Books, since
which tho we have passed all the holidays which is the time to sell
I have not been able to dispose of a single Sett, they all com=
plain the books are too large and heavy. So much so that I
have orders for three Setts if printed on thin paper like your Daily
Services, and as they fear you will not have them bound as
they wish, that is to say one of the persons, he requests you will
send him out an unbound Sett if on thin paper, his object is to
cut off the margins as much as possible, and then have
them bound in smaller vols. according to his own taste
they being for a very young lady who could not well
hold ones of these books in her hands the time she should
in consequence of the weight, the other two setts you will
please send according to the order enclosed, all three
Setts are bespoken consequently they must be

according to the order, and those you cant fulfill (if
any) according to the order do not send at all as I
am exposed to receive them on my hands, you would
do well also to put up a few setts more for me to sell
with at least the kipur books divided in two or three, and
always on thin paper, as those heavy books will not sell.
the west India ladies will not use them, the English
editions being so much smaller or lighter. I am very
much obliged to you for the notice you took of my dear
wife's death. The sentiments expressed being your own
I am doubly thankful. I would surmise in the price
of the books you charge them 5 per cent over your price as
here 5 franc pieces pay for Dollars, and if you require re=
mittance in that specie you will have to loose the dif=
-ference, however you do not mention any thing of that
in yr letter as I may perhaps have to shew it to them.

In your kind favor of 2nd May. I perceive w/ much
pleasure your promise to send my sister Mrs.
Lindo a number of the Occident I have written her
to that effect, and have requested her to apply to your
agents in London, if she does not hear from them,
with the sett of prayer Books here in ordered to be
sent unbound please send (on same sort paper & same ?)
a Sett of Pentateuch unbound, as the person wishes to
have them, forming one complete Sett all bound alike
and all printed alike. I will copy below this the
order he has given me in his own words to avoid mis=
takes. Hoping you have passed pleasantly the holidays & that you may
see many happy returns of them. I am yr Sincere friend.

PS. In your favor of 2nd: March, you say the Books I
ordered for Pto Cabello will go by the next packet,
now I do not recollect having ordered any Books
for Pto Cabo., or any where else, if you have sent
any please let me know.—

One Ditto Pentateuch all printed on thin
paper, to be unbound, the person wants to get
them bound here, that he may divide them to his liking
and his motive for wishing thin paper's because
he wanted them for his young daughter, consequently
he wants them light, if they cant be sent according
to his desine do not send them.

The foregoing is duplicate of my last respects
since which I have recd. yr. favors 3 Oct. & 31st and the
Books correct as per your notes.

Mr. Dacosta left this morning for St. Thomas to
fetch out his sister who is coming out from England
to join him here,

I am afraid you will never see the money if
the books Mr. Lobo of Puerto Cavello had from you
ask is not the best paymaster, I hope tho' it
will prove otherwise.—wishing you well, and
with respect I am Dr Sir yrs. Truly
Encld. A letter recd for you
